slidelink.displaytext: Module #2 The Lifecycle of a Clinical Rotation
Curricular Framework and Effective Clinical Instruction
Characteristics of an Effective Clinical Teacher: Reflect & Consider
Characteristics of an Effective Clinical Teacher
Preparing for the Clinical Rotation: Summary
Clinical Orientation: Who, Where, When, What, Why?
Examples of Resources Aubrey will Use
Implementing Effective Clinical Teaching During the Clinical Rotation: Summary
Winding Down the Clinical Rotation - Summary
Scenario – A bump in the road...

search.slidetext: module #2 the lifecycle of a clinical rotation please click anywhere on the image to get started

additional resources and reference materials are linked throughout the module where applicable. you may also access these documents from the resources link in the upper right corner of the screen. additional resources navigate this module by selecting the forward and backward arrows < > in the bottom right corner of the screen or by using the menu on the left. navigating the module instructions there are instances throughout the module where the forward arrow is not visible until you complete one or several required actions. these may include clicking a button to open a new slide; click the icon to close those slides if the next arrow is not visible.

please enter your name below to populate the certificate of completion at the end of the module. your responses to exercises throughout the module will be available to the course organizers for data collection, but these will be anonymous and your name will not be associated with your responses. however, quercus will register if you have completed the module or not. first name last name introduction in this module, the lifecycle of a clinical rotation will be explored and discussed to support you in your preparation and development as a clinical instructor. fostering effective relationships preparing for the clinical rotation developing effective clinical teaching activities this module will share creative clinical teaching strategies, ideas and resources for you to consider using in your clinical teaching practice.

identify appropriate clinical teaching activities to ensure supportive learning environments and student progression through the clinical rotation. identify effective clinical teaching activities 3 describe the ci role and responsibilities during the planning, implementing and winding down phases of the clinical rotation. describe phases of the clinical rotation 2 articulate the importance of establishing and maintaining excellent interpersonal relationships with both students and staff during the clinical rotation. articulate interpersonal relationships 1 learning outcomes
curricular framework and effective clinical instruction

lbfon curricular framework lbfon curricular themes vision mission values all course learning outcomes and clinical practice expectations (cpes) are structured within these curricular themes. the themes are consistent with the educational and professional practice requirements outlined by both the college of nurses of ontario and the canadian nurses association. the course outcomes and clinical practice expectations will serve as the roadmap for minimum learning expectations. it is important that you understand these and use them to structure the clinical learning activities for your students. the complexity and breadth of the cpes grow as the student progresses through the undergraduate program.

health teaching and promotion tailored to client and family context and strengths across various care levels and settings promotion of health & capacity building equity, social justice, determinants of health across continuum of care close safe, ethical &competent practice professional behaviour (accountability, responsibility, self regulation) knowledge, skill and judgement required for safe and ethical nursing practice close examination of how one’s own values, perspectives and positionality are similar and different to the client/family’s centrality of relationships relational skills in building therapeutic relationships with clients and families integration of contextually based philosophies of care (person/child/family-centred care) close interdisciplinarity and interprofessional collaboration collaboration and communication within nursing and with a range of health care team members in achieving common goal of quality health care leadership skills including advocacy, negotiation and delegation close seek out, critically examine, synthesize, integrate, evaluate and use multiple sources of evidence to provide high quality nursing care and improve outcomes process of questioning and investigating; identifying and challenging assumptions, imagining and exploring alternatives critical reflection on action, reflective reasoning close scholarship and critical inquiry scholarship & critical inquiry safe, ethical &competent practice safe, ethical &competent practice interdisciplinarity & interprofessional collaboration centrality of relationships promotion of health & capacity building lbfon curricular framework click each theme to learn more please visit all of the themes to move on lbfon curricular themes please wait for the explanation to finish before moving on.

please fill in your answer before moving on. what do you think are the some of the most important characteristics (or qualities) of an effective clinical teacher? characteristics of an effective clinical teacher type your text here being an effective clinical instructor is necessary for student learning and for developing supportive learning environments.

interpersonal relationships with students next, we’ll look at each of these characteristics in detail references: hanson & stenvig, 2008; melrose, park & perry, 2022; oermann, shellenbarger & gaberson, 2018 the characteristics of an effective clinical teacher have been widely researched and reported in the nursing education literature. interpersonal relationships with students personal characteristics personal characteristics not the most important try again! personal characteristics skill in clinical teaching skill in clinical teaching not the most important try again! skill in clinical teaching clinical competence clinical competence not the most important try again! clinical competence knowledge knowledge not the most important try again! knowledge characteristics of an effective clinical teacher think about your own qualities and behaviours that will promote and support your students' clinical learning

concepts & theories evidence based practice and technologies clinical placement student backgrounds clinical course content & practice expectations knowledge to be effective, the clinical instructor must have a strong knowledge base, excellent clinical judgment, and the ability to share this knowledge with students. characteristics of an effective clinical teacher

excellent nursing practice maintain clinical skills clinical expert to be effective, the clinical instructor must have and demonstrate clinical competence at all times. clinical competence characteristics of an effective clinical teacher

be an excellent role model keep students challenged be organized know how to teach guide & evaluate learning outcomes plan appropriate clinical activities assess students' learning needs to be effective, the clinical instructor must have developed or developing skill in clinical teaching. support student learning skill in clinical teaching characteristics of an effective clinical teacher

strong, professional, nursing identity be open, fair, honest, and dependable enjoy teaching caring well prepared confident responsible active listener approachable enthusiastic patient flexible friendly the clinical instructor's personal characteristics play a major role in keeping students motivated and interested in learning. personal characteristics characteristics of an effective clinical teacher

be approachable be genuine, direct and honest demonstrate trust and respect for diversity references: hanson & stenvig, 2008; melrose et al., 2015; oermann et al., 2018 display empathic understanding interpersonal relationships with students students report interpersonal relationships as one of the most important characteristics of being an effective clinical teacher.

student stressors in clinical practice fear of making a mistake being unfamiliar with the clinical setting lacking the knowledge and skill to provide patient care caring for patients with varying conditions and acuity experiencing a deteriorating patient situation interacting with patients, staff, other health care providers interacting with and being observed by their clinical teacher reference oermann et al., 2018 reflection in many studies, the clinical teacher and their behaviours created the most stress for students. this highlights the importance of developing supportive and trusting ci / student relationships to help minimize this stress and support student learning. the ci must always be aware of the stressful nature of clinical learning activities. do you remember what it was like to be a nursing student? do you remember what you found to be the most stressful? what do you think some of the stressors might be for your nursing students? and how might these influence how you provide a supportive clinical learning environment?

interpersonal relationships with staff be a positive role model maintain strong relationships for safe patient care and to enhance student learning employ communication skills to clarify expectations develop collaborative and authentic relationships with staff establishing relationships with staff is an important teaching quality and necessary to help create a supportive learning environment.

correct that's right! clinical competence is the characteristic best demonstrated in the scenario. continue continue continue continue continue continue incorrect please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you did not select the correct response. clinical competence is the characteristic best demonstrated in the scenario. continue continue continue continue continue continue a. knowledge a. knowledge a. knowledge a. knowledge a. knowledge a. knowledge b. clinical competence b. clinical competence b. clinical competence b. clinical competence b. clinical competence b. clinical competence c. skill in clinical teaching c. skill in clinical teaching c. skill in clinical teaching c. skill in clinical teaching c. skill in clinical teaching c. skill in clinical teaching d. interpersonal relationships d. interpersonal relationships d. interpersonal relationships d. interpersonal relationships d. interpersonal relationships d. interpersonal relationships e. personal characteristics e. personal characteristics e. personal characteristics e. personal characteristics e. personal characteristics e. personal characteristics knowledge check the clinical instructor completes a complex dressing change with a senior year student while role modeling expert practice knowledge and skill. which of the following characteristics of being an effective clinical teacher is best demonstrated in this scenario? the clinical instructor completes a complex dressing change with a senior year student while role modeling expert practice knowledge and skill. which of the following characteristics of being an effective clinical teacher is best demonstrated in this scenario? the clinical instructor completes a complex dressing change with a senior year student while role modeling expert practice knowledge and skill. which of the following characteristics of being an effective clinical teacher is best demonstrated in this scenario? question 1/2 select your answer and click the check mark at bottom right. you have two attempts.

correct that's right! it is important for the clinical instructor to be aware of how stressful the clinical experience can be for students, and to reassure students that their role is to help them cope with these potential stressors continue continue continue continue continue continue incorrect you did not select the correct response. it is true that it is important for the clinical instructor to be aware of how stressful the clinical experience can be for students, and to reassure students that their role is to help them cope with these potential stressors. continue continue continue continue continue continue true true true true true true false false false false false false it is important for the clinical instructor to be aware of how stressful the clinical experience can be for students, and to reassure students that their role is to help them cope with these potential stressors. it is important for the clinical instructor to be aware of how stressful the clinical experience can be for students, and to reassure students that their role is to help them cope with these potential stressors. it is important for the clinical instructor to be aware of how stressful the clinical experience can be for students, and to reassure students that their role is to help them cope with these potential stressors. knowledge check select your answer and click the check mark at bottom right. you have one attempt. question 2/2
phases of the clinical rotation

how will i facilitate the successful completion of the clinical rotation? how will i be most effective as a clinical instructor during the clinical rotation? phase 2 implementation phase 2 implementation phase 2 implementation how will i prepare myself and my students for the clinical rotation? phase 1 preparation phase 1 preparation phase 1 preparation phase 3 winding down phase 3 winding down phase 3 winding down click phase 1 to continue click phase 2 to continue click phase 3 to continue please wait for the introduction to finish before continuing
preparation phase
type your first text here my checklist: things i will do to prepare for my clinical rotation clinical orientation: how to prepare

review unit specific policies opportunities for job shadowing (senior year students) plan for downtime review safety… safe practice, ppe be aware of your own biases back back back back back back 3 of 3 please read each sticky note before moving on! compile list of most common diseases and medications on the unit to help students prepare prepare to set clear expectations with students and ask them what their expectations are plan activities in advance ie: inservices during rotation housekeeping ie: organize lockers, id badges email students to introduce / describe yourself, tell them where to meet you on first day more more more more more more 2 of 3 back back back back back back please read each sticky note before moving on! examples of what to prepare email unit manager /educator, introduce self as ci, visit / shadow / orient to unit share information about the student group’s level of education, their roles and responsibilities & scope of practice book meeting room / classroom for orientation day and weekly post conferences plan a ‘hands on’ orientation ie: practice taking vs, using equipment, scavenger hunt, hospital and unit tour, medication quiz plan ice breaker activities, learning style assessment, asking students about previous clinical experiences (positive and negative), learning goals, assess any student concerns more more more more more more 1 of 3 please read each sticky note before moving on!

clinical orientation why? what? when? where? who? the clinical orientation day is primarily for you the ci, and your assigned group of nursing students. it is a good idea to also invite the unit manager and educator to attend at some point to formally welcome the students. the clinical orientation day should take place at the hospital placement site... primarily in a classroom (which you will need to book ahead of time) and on the unit. the clinical orientation day occurs at the very beginning of each clinical rotation, on the first clinical day. ideally, this is followed by an opportunity for students to spend some time shadowing a nurse caring for patients on the unit. the clinical orientation day includes a variety of relational, preparation and learning opportunities which we'll discuss next. the clinical orientation day has many purposes including: preparing students to care for patients and families in a particular clinical setting; establishing a safe, positive and supportive learning environment; and establishing beginning ci – student relationships & group relationships.

preparing for the clinical rotation: summary send out welcome email to clinical group of students think about, prepare and deliver a clinical orientation for the students on the first clinical day think about and plan clinical learning activities review course learning outcomes and clinical practice expectations orient self to the clinical area and patient / client population note: if the ci does not work on the assigned unit for their clinical teaching role, it is imperative that they spend some time shadowing on the unit to become familiar with the clinical setting, patient population, policies & procedures, unit resources, etc. all cis should: contact the unit to arrange a short meeting with the manager & educator to discuss the upcoming clinical rotation and your role as the ci. you should confirm the assigned clinical days and times, and gather resources to help you orient yourself and your students to the clinical setting: things like a list of common patient diagnoses, medications, procedures, unit scavenger hunt, etc. these resources often exist as they would be used for orienting new rn staff to unit. preparing for the clinical rotation summary:

facilitating clinical post conferences click to view the article: read the article read the article read the article provides an excellent opportunity to help students explore situations which may be complex, unpredictable, and/or have ethical questions the article by kelly, henry & williams (2019) shares a practical approach (using the debriefing method) to facilitate effective post clinical conferences. questions can encourage students to think through and problem solve situations by asking questions about a student’s views and sharing their own experiences, the clinical instructor can help students gain valuable insight about themselves effective clinical teaching
clinical orientation: what to include? my checklist: things that will be included in my clinical orientation day

preparing patient assignments patients should be selected based on: the clinical practice expectations (cpes) the student’s needs, interests and abilities the needs & acuity of the patient the learning opportunities available remember, the cpes help provide a road map for cis to help students apply their classroom theory. benner: their “knowing that”, to their clinical practice or their “knowing how.” it should be clear to students how each of their assigned patients will help them to develop their knowledge, skill and abilities required to meet their cpes. effective clinical teaching

meet ci aubrey prior to beginning the clinical rotation, aubrey considers potential ways to structure and facilitate the clinical orientation day with her students. aubrey has been a staff nurse on this adult general medical surgical unit for the past 8 years. she has been a clinical instructor for another nursing school in the recent past. aubrey has been hired as the ci for a group of nursing students coming to complete their adult med/surg clinical placement on her home unit.

aubrey's clinical orientation day agenda get photo ids done, locker assignment, confirm computer training date and time welcome and introductions (ice breaker activities) meet the unit manager and educator review and discuss clinical practice expectations (and clinical course learning outcomes), ci and student expectations, important university policies review and discuss important hospital policies, infection control, unit routines, patient population, common diagnoses and medications, typical clinical day actively look through patient chart including labs, diagnostic tests, flow sheets, kardex, medication record; discuss charting expectations meet outside the tim horton’s near main entrance tour of the hospital ending in clinical unit classroom morning: 9:00 9:30 11:30

student activity (all about me card), open q&a unit tour and scavenger hunt orientation to empty patient room practice safety checks (call bell, oxygen and suction set up, emergency equipment), practice operating bed review and/or practice clinical skills and assessments, discuss patient safety, patient and family centred care, ‘what to do when’ scenarios practice charting and medication calculations, do medication quiz and take up lunch break afternoon: 12:00 13:00 14:30 end 15:00 note: provide resources, written or electronic documents of things covered during the orientation day as students won't remember everything! aubrey's clinical orientation day agenda

to: transitioning from staff nurse to clinical faculty, part 2 ❑ id/allergy band ❑ oxygen triple bar + test if each works ❑ medical air + test if it works ❑ suction apparatus + test if it works, and if there is the proper suction catheters or yanker suction (or soft tip suction) present. ❑ emergency equipment cupboard contains appropriate masks for the size of your patient. ❑ resuscitation sheets - weight up to date ❑ call bell in reach of patient or parents. ❑ assess ese (entanglement) and falls risk. document ese/falls on kidcare - if high risk, develop a safety plan. ❑ assess for any other safety risks or needs of your patient. student resources pocket book safely check ** done at start of shift** ❑ id/allergy band ❑ oxygen triple bar + test if each works ❑ medical air + test if it mechanics of breathing retractions tracheal tug nasal flaring head bobbing grunting on exhalation prolonged expiratory phase diminished air entry change in breath sounds stridor wheezing late signs of respiratory distress skin colour changes-dusky/cynotic inaudible air entry apnea/irregular respiration changes in level of consciousness/activity bradycardia red flags of cardiovascular collapse tachycardia altered perfusion skin prolonged capillary refill > 2 sec increased core to skin temperature gradient brain altered level of consciousness/activity decreased response, “worried” appearance kidneys decreased urinary output <1ml/kg/hr decrease in pulse quality late signs decreased response to pain flaccid tone hypotension bradycardia back back back back back back airway / breathing first 10kg) + ( 50ml for each kg 11-20) + (20 ml for each additional kg) / 24hour example: calculate the hourly maintenance fluid rate for a child who weighs 25kg (100ml x 10kg) + (50ml x 10kg) + (20ml x 5kg) / 24hrs (1000ml) + (500ml) + (100ml) = 1600ml / 24hrs = 66.7ml/hr using this formula the hourly fluid maintenance for this child is 67ml/hr using this formula the hourly fluid maintenance for this child is 67ml/hr 4 / 2 / 1 method (4ml/kg for the first 10kg) + (2ml/kg for kg 11-20) + (1ml/kg for every kg above 20) = hourly rate example: calculate the hourly maintenance fluid rate for a child who weighs 25kg (4ml x 10kg) + (2ml x 10kg) + (1ml x 5kg) = hourly rate 40ml + 20ml + 5ml = 65ml/hr using the 4/2/1 method, this child's hourly maintenance fluid rate is 65ml/hr using the 4/2/1 method, this child's hourly maintenance fluid rate is 65ml/hr student resources pocket book calculating maintenance fluid rates aka tfi (total fluid intake) formula method (100 ml for each of the first 10kg) + ( 50ml for each kg 11-20) + (20 ml for each additional kg) / 24hour example: calculate the hourly maintenance fluid rate for a child who weighs 25kg (100ml x 10kg) + (50ml x 10kg) + (20ml x 5kg) / 24hrs (1000ml) + (500ml) + (100ml) = 1600ml / 24hrs = 66.7ml/hr 4 / 2 / 1 method (4ml/kg for the first 10kg) + (2ml/kg for kg 11-20) + (1ml/kg for every kg above 20) = hourly rate example: calculate the hourly maintenance fluid rate for a child who weighs 25kg (4ml x 10kg) + (2ml x 10kg) + (1ml x 5kg) = hourly rate 40ml + 20ml + 5ml = 65ml/hr using the 4/2/1 method, this child's hourly maintenance fluid rate is 65ml/hr urine output amount / weight in kg / hrs = _____ cc/kg/hr eg: total urine output 80cc, pt wt = 9kg, 8hr 80cc/9kg/8hr = 1.11cc/kg/hr urinary output in paediatric patients *calculated in ml/kg/hr. ❑ normal: 1 - 2ml/kg/hr ❑ oliguria: <1.0ml/kg/hr ❑ anuria: no urine output ❑ polyuria: > 3ml/kg/hr student resources pocket book calculating urine output (cc/kg/hr) urine output amount / weight in kg / hrs =__ cc/kg/hr ex. total urine output 80cc, pt wt = 9kg, 8hr 80cc/9kg/8hr = 1.11cc/kg/hr urinary output in paediatric patients *calculated in ml/kg/hr. ❑ normal: 1 - 2ml/kg/hr ❑ oliguria: <1.0ml/kg/hr ❑ anuria: no urine output ❑ polyuria: > 3ml/kg/hr 0700-0730: read patient careplan & night handover with your rn buddy 0730-0800: day huddles (discuss patient safety concerns, etc); discuss your plan of the day with your rn buddy 0800-0900: morning vs, meds* 10:00-1200: medical team rounds for each patient. please join in! first break (30min) 1200-1300: noon vs (if q4h) // bathe pt if needed/ meds 13:00-1400: start writing apie note 16:00-1700: vs / meds / second break (1hr) 1800-1900: handover *meds = always with your nurse or ci **fridays = post conference at 1730-1830, no apie note student resources pocket book day time schedule (thursday 12hr) 0700-0730: read patient careplan & night handover with your rn buddy 0730-0800: day huddles (discuss patient safety concerns, etc); discuss your plan of the day with your rn buddy 0800-0900: morning vs, meds* 10:00-1200: medical team rounds for each patient. please join in! first break (30min) 1200-1300: noon vs (if q4h) // bathe pt if needed/ meds 13:00-1400: start writing apie note16:00-1700: vs / meds / second break (1hr) 1800-1900: handover *meds = always with your nurse or ci **fridays = post conference at 1730-1830, no apie note bravery beads!!! spend time building your therapeutic relationship with your patient and their family. assess if your patient needs a bath or sheets to be changed. you can offer to watch the child so the parent can go get a coffee or grab some food downstairs. look up your child’s condition. ask if you can help others. ask your family if they have received print-outs from www.aboutkidshealth.ca regarding the medications their child is on and/or their medical condition. student resources pocket book are your bored? ● bravery beads!!! ● spend time building your therapeutic relationship with your patient and their family. ● assess if your patient needs a bath or sheets to be changed. ● you can offer to watch the child so the parent can go get a coffee or grab some food downstairs. ● look up your child’s condition. ● ask if you can help others. ● ask your family if they have received print-outs from www.aboutkidshealth.ca regarding the medications their child is on and/or their medical condition. in paediatric practice medication, dosages are calculated based on the child’s weight, making the dosages much more precise. it is important that the child’s most recent weight in kilograms is entered into the kidcare system so that drug dosage calculations are accurate. is your dose within therapeutic range? use the sickkids’ formulary, or “e-formulary”, to check if the prescribed dose is within a therapeutic range. another source of information is the electronic cps (ecps) found on the hospital internal webpage. student resources pocket book medication calculation in paediatric practice, medication dosages are calculated based on the child’s weight, making the dosages much more precise. it is important that the child’s most recent weight in kilograms is entered into the kidcare system so that drug dosage calculations are accurate. is your dose within therapeutic range? use the sickkids’ formulary, or “e-formulary”, to check if the prescribed dose is within a therapeutic range. another source of information is the electronic cps (ecps) found on the hospital internal webpage. 3 checks before iv medication administration: 1) compatibility to maintenance line 2) dilution 3) rate - how fast are you infusing? use the online “iv medication administration guidelines” found in the mar (epic) to check reconstitution and stability guidelines, administration guidelines, implications and side effects. student resources pocket book iv medication administration guidelines 3 checks before iv (sickkids) ❏ utilize computers in patient room to sign off patient and medications ❏ vital signs and iv fluid balance can be easily updated at the bedside ❏ meds: **remember your rights ** 1) in med room - scan medication (pending) 2) in patient room - scan patient id band to insure correct patient 3) administer medication to patient 4) sign off medication on mar in patient room student resources pocket book: documentation: apie documentation: apie ** at sickkids we use a charting format called “apie” for our progress notes. ❑ assessment - subjective and objective data. include pews scores. this is your patient assessment, circumstances, conversations, patient/family education needs, etc… ❑ planning - includes nursing plans, and family goals for treatment. this should not include plans of other professionals as they will document their own plans. ❑ implementation - what was done? ❑ evaluation - did it work? how it worked? what changes you need to make if it didn’t work. this is from your perspective as a nurse and from the perspective of the patient/family perspective. student resources pocket book doc epic ** at sickkids we use a charting format called “apie” for our progress notes. ❑ assessment subjective and objective data. include pews scores. this is your patient assessment, circumstances, conversations, patient/family education needs, etc. ❑ planning includes nursing plans, and family goals for treatment. this should not include plans of other professionals as they will document their own plans. ❑ implementation what was done? ❑ evaluation did it work? how it worked? what changes you need to make if it didn’t work. this is from your perspective as a nurse and from the perspective of the patient/family perspective. student resources pocket book doc apie student resources pocket book student resources pocket book: hourly check (aka sign off) hourly check aka sign off * each hour you check in on your patient. ** always keep your nurse up to date with what you are doing and your patients’ status. ❑ assess if their status has changed or if they need anything. document any changes on the flowsheet. ❑ make sure their environment is safe. ❑ document any vital signs from the monitor (if on monitors). ❑ notify rn if you have any concerns or updates. ❑ document intake/output. - hourly iv site inspection, iv rate & vtbi // tlc - touch, look, compare - medications given (iv, po, ng, gtube) * each hour you check in on your patient. ** always keep your nurse up to date with what you are doing and your patients’ status. ❑ assess if their status has changed or if they need anything. document any changes on the flow sheet. ❑ make sure their environment is safe. ❑ document any vital signs from the monitor (if on monitors). ❑ notify rn if you have any concerns or updates. ❑ document intake/output. - hourly iv site inspection, iv rate & vtbi // tlc - touch, look, compare hourly check (aka sign off) student resources pocket book vitals & documentation * frequency will be a doctor’s order. as per pews = q4h ❑ pews score (must be reviewed and signed by rn) - pews score determines vital frequency. ❑ pain - indicated which pain scale was used. ❑ blood pressure - automatic/doppler/manual ❑ temperature - indicated if it was done oral, axillary or rectal. ❑ heart rate (listen for 1 minute at apex) - document if any unique heart sounds are present, such as a murmur. - check peripheral pulses and assess if patient is warm peripherally. ❑ respiratory rate (listen for 1 minute) - document a full respiratory assessment ❑ capillary refill - check nail bed < or > 3 seconds ❑ sedation status (are they awake? asleep? if they are lethargic, how rouseable are they?) ❑ listen for bowel sounds in all four quadrants. ❑ document anything interesting that you feel is important. student resources pocket book vitals student resources pocket book examples of resources aubrey will use safety check safety check safety check vitals and resources, written or electronic documents of things covered during the orientation day as students won't remember everything! ice breaker activities student impressions student impressions student impressions two truths and a lie two truths and a lie two truths and a lie i’ve never… i’ve never… i’ve never… human knot human knot human knot name game name game name game fill in their blank fill in their blank fill in their blank click on each activity to learn more about it each person shares what are they excited about and what are they nervous about as they begin this clinical rotation. going around the circle, each person shares two things about them that are true and one thing that is a lie… the group has to guess the lie (could be done in pairs and shared with group). going around the circle, each person completes the sentence “i have never… “ specifically related to nursing practice. everyone who has done the thing that the speaker has never done gives the speaker a reward (each person starts with one piece of candy for every person in group). the group forms a close circle, each person puts their right hand in the middle of the circle and holds the hand of a player who is not to their immediate left or right. repeat this using the left hand ensuring everyone is holding the hand of a different person than before. the group must now untangle themselves into a circle without letting go of one another. sit in a circle and pick a theme (e.g.: food). each person will introduce themselves by saying their name and a word that starts with the same letter of their name (e.g.: my name is mary ann and i like mini wheats). as you go around the circle everyone must repeat the previous person’s statement(s) followed by their own. this continues until the last person recites everyone’s name and word. ask each person to write a fill-in-the-blank sticky note or index card… collect the responses and put them in a hat. going around the circle, have each person pull one sticky note / index card out of the hat and complete the sentence. for example, “if i had a soundtrack to my life, it would be _________.”. examples of resources aubrey will use typical clinical day during the day; some tasks required or to think about: review epic frequently to see if there are new np/md orders bathing and linen changes adls encourage activity as tolerated/ordered to be able to get out of bed (ex. accompany pt with a walk around the unit, get help with staff rn to get pt into a wheelchair) treatments or tests (you can accompany pt) specific skills ex. do they need a cvl dressing change today? earlier the better** draft your apie note and write once received ci approval encourage and support parents to take care of themselves. volunteer to stay in room with patient if they want to shower or go downstairs to get food. further research diagnoses/meds, work on your patho/nursing care plan worksheet ** please do not sit around nursing station, if you have run out of things to do, come talk to me and we can find some good learning opportunities** 0650 meet at windows outside of 5c with ci 0650 - 0710 review patient care plans (note any changes from the day before) review patient diagnosis review medications and any allergies organize yourself and think of what you need to prioritize today! 0710 - 0745 introduce yourself to the staff rn inform the rn what care you will and will not be providing (ex. will be doing all vs/assessments, piv monitoring, ins/outs, but no medications today) listen to report by night shift rn ask any questions to rn or ci regarding report or for clarification nursing handover at the bedside 0745 - 0830 introduce yourself to patients and families. make eye contact. listen perform safety check: emergency box in room is full, locked and tag is not expired o2 valves in room are functioning suction equipment available and functional pt has appropriate id band on and allergy band if necessary ** verify patient name and dob with pt or parent if patient is ordered a monitor, that they are on one. staff rn will look at limits?? perform head to toe assessment and vital signs (once approved by ci) document safety check and vs/assessments/ins/outs in kidcare if you have a baby check if they need daily weights and head circumference **if pt has 0800 meds, speak to ci before you go into room to arrange this** 0900 common morning medication time 1000 - 1030 give report to your staff rn regarding your patient and what time you will be back 1st break x 45 mins at 1015? 1130 - 1230 start vitals and assessments if due (usually if ordered q4h) give any medications that are due check patient fluid balances did you input all the values correctly for the am? miss any diapers? 1300 - 1530 start vitals and assessments if due (usually if ordered q6h to q8h) continue with ins/outs as necessary perform any care necessary write apie note once you have ci approval 1500 - 1515 give report to your staff rn regarding your patient and what time/if you will be back 2nd break x 45 mins 1545 - 1630 on thursdays start vitals and assessments if due (usually if ordered q4h) give any medications that are due check patient fluid balances did you input all the values correctly since lunch? miss any diapers? 1700 on thursdays give report to your staff rn regarding any changes with the patient and anything that still needs to be completed for the remainder of the shift 0650 - 0745 0650 - 0745 0650 - 0745 0745 - 0900 0745 - 0900 0745 - 0900 1000 - 1515 1000 - 1515 1000 - 1515 thursdays 1545 - 1700 thursdays 1545 - 1700 thursdays 1545 - 1700 daily tasks daily tasks daily tasks click each button to learn more common medications cardiac, antihypertensive cardiac, antihypertensive cardiac, antihypertensive diuretics /magnesium/calcium supplements 5. prednisone click a category below to see the list of common medications associated with it: seizure seizure seizure last updated january 2020 click a category below to see the list of common diagnoses and treatments associated with it: pre/postop care grid patient brain tumours post fossa syndrome vp shunt hydrocephalus myelomeningocele (mmc) moya moya disease craniotomy hemispherectomy lobectomy chiari ii malformation arterial venous malformation (avm) craniopharyngioma tethered cord spinal tumour external ventricular drain (evd) lumbar drain vagal nerve common diagnoses and medications examples of resources aubrey will use common diagnoses common diagnoses common diagnoses common medications common medications common medications answer the following questions: what is the phone number for the unit? how does the call bell system work? how do you get help quickly if you need it? where is the diet sheet or record of the patients’ diets? how would you find out if a patient is on swallowing precautions? where would you be able to get a drink of milk or juice for your client? how will you know a client’s activity level or when to use a mechanical lift? if a resident were to ask you to get them to the bathroom quickly, what information do you need to safely respond? where are the clean linen supplies? adult briefs? skin care products? where do you place used linens or patient clothing needing to be washed? which patients use the tub or shower and where are they located? where are the staff assignments or teams posted? number of rns, lpns and hcas? where will the patient assignment sheets be posted? where would you find information on the resident’s last bowel movement? if they haven’t had a bm for several days, where do you look for bowel care orders or protocols? where are the blood pressure cuffs and stethoscopes? do they have an o2 sat monitor? a manual and an electronic bp cuff? does this unit have access to oxygen equipment or suction? where are the fire alarms, extinguishers and exits? how do you respond as a student if the fire alarm goes off? how do you respond if you witness a cardiac arrest? your client is worried about being ready for the physiotherapist’s visit this morning. how do you know when the physio will be arriving? a patient has just had an accident on the way to the bathroom. how will you handle the clean up? is this your responsibility or the house keeping staff? where will you take your break or get a drink of water? back back back back back back seek and find for orientation day complete the “seek and find” in teams of two. we’ll discuss any questions which you were not able to answer at the end of the activity. **please be vigilant about maintaining the privacy and confidentiality of patient information as you access charts to complete this activity. ask for permission before entering any patient rooms. consider the impact on the patients and their privacy when you visit the dining room, hall or lounges. select a patient chart with your partner and search out the following details: physician’s or doctor’s order sheet - where is the most current order? nursing narrative notes or patient progress record- what type of charting do they complete on a daily basis? monthly? admission history - when and why was this client admitted to the unit? intake assessment - was an adl assessment included? list of conditions - how would you determine the conditions that are a priority for this client? current concerns vs conditions which are no longer a problem for the client? discharge planning - how do you find information on when this patient is scheduled to be discharged from the unit? medication list dnr orders and advanced directives more more more more more more lynda champoux bsn, instructor, department of nursing, camosun college, victoria, bc. https://www.casn.ca/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/clinical-interest-group-document-2015-final.pdf scavenger hunt for students 1. find the following items: reception desk clean and dirty utility rooms glucometer and supplies nursing assignment book medication frig pxyis machine pantry/nutrition/ice machine code?_______ fire alarms linen supply fire exits fire extinguishers and hoses staff washroom staff refrigerator for lunches _________ staff room code________ blanket warmer report area designated area for eating (please note that patient charts are not allowed in these areas) tub room patient call system -unit call system (how does it work - ask the unit secretary for a demonstration) bedside, bathroom, emergency staff and public washrooms clean supply room 2. find a chart that no one is using right now and locate the following parts of the chart: clinical notes uhn vascular access record doctor’s orders 3. find the labels that you can use for patient positive identification for medication administration 4. where would you find new medical orders? 1. __________________2.________________________ 5. where would you document care completed to the patient’s vascular access line (picc, piv, cvc) ____________________________________________ 6. where would you document your physical assessment and add narrative nursing notes?____________________________________________ 7. find where on the nursing unit, the kardex and the paper mars for any chemotherapy agents and the pre-medications are kept. please note - the paper mars may contain other medications which are given as an infusion (e.g. heparin) once you have your epr access, you will need to complete electronic charting on each patient each day. the areas for electronic charting will be covered today scavenger hunt please locate: fire hose two nursing stations nursing education- staff room nurse manager’s office beds 172-1,188-1 185-4,178 telemetry leads in the dressing baskets in room 183 patient education room patients’ pantry: ice machine, styrofoam cups cruch card staff washroom munk elevators eaton elevators staff lounge (code) stairwell ward clerk desk patient education classes schedule telemetry report iv insertion baskets public washroom clinical educator’s room kitchen telemetry room what is the name of the rn taking care of the patient in the room 172-2? who is the staff doctor of this patient? who is the np? find the chart of this patient do the same for a patient in room 180 clean utility room: gauze 4x4 sterile gloves oxygen tanks nasal prongs mepilex with border ns 1000 ml bag bedpan telemetry pouches paper tape telemetry batteries diapers wound care kit medication rooms: 10 cc syringe iv primary set iv pump set medication cups novolin toronto diabetes snack fridge hypoglycaemia policy iv secondary set iv meds compatibility chart insulin syringe winding down phase

my checklist: things i will do to maintain a supportive learning environment as my students complete their clinical rotation: winding down phase: reflect & consider type your first text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here

back back back back back back 3 of 3 next steps… next learning goals… review things to apply to next rotation wrapping up with relationships (manager, team lead) increase responsibility begin writing evaluations get feedback on ci from students, peer review cheerlead! recap accomplishments, celebrate! please read each sticky note before moving on! more more more more more more back back back back back back ask students how they think they’ve done so far (feedback) 2 of 3 continuous checks with staff, resolve conflicts quickly checking expectations encourage ongoing reflection - what went well and not so well, what worries they have any new experiences missed? available? increase workload (1-2 or 3 pts as appropriate) pair outgoing student with quiet one please read each sticky note before moving on! examples of previous ci’s ideas post conferences - give students topics to discuss in post conference / round table discussions… how was your day - identify the good and bad… open discussion and follow up / check-ins… ideas of case scenarios… case presentation and student led “what would you like me to do differently to enhance your learning?” “do you feel like you have missed something?” think about what’s left for each student to view, practice, observe more more more more more more 1 of 3 identify individual student goals and try to meet the learning goal figure out what i still need to see from students… cpe check-in click each sticky note to reveal their ideas! please read each sticky note before moving on!

aubrey’s plan for winding down ? review cpes again review cpes again ? ? review clinical notes thoroughly to ensure continued variety of patient assignments and skill opportunities review clinical notes thoroughly to ensure continued variety of patient assignments and skill opportunities ? ? try to capture staff nurse feedback regarding each student in clinical notes – good examples and quotes to include in evaluation try to capture staff nurse feedback regarding each student in clinical notes – good examples and quotes to include in evaluation ? ? follow up with course faculty regarding any student concerns or questions follow up with course faculty regarding any student concerns or questions ? ? invite students to develop and share a few specific learning goals for final weeks, remind them to complete their self-assessments invite students to develop and share a few specific learning goals for final weeks, remind them to complete their self-assessments ? ? touch base with nurse educator / manager to share overall student group progress and thank them for their support touch base with nurse educator / manager to share overall student group progress and thank them for their support ? ? become familiar with the online system for completing student evaluations and begin writing final evaluations using cpes in a word document become familiar with the online system for completing student evaluations and begin writing final evaluations using cpes in a word document ? ? try to capture staff nurse feedback regarding each student in clinical notes – good examples and quotes to include in evaluation keep students engaged and motivated to continue developing their clinical practice, organization and time management skills ? ? follow up with faculty / clinical coordinator regarding any student concerns or questions encourage staff nurses to help promote student independence... providing assistance only when necessary and/or requested ? ? invite students to develop and share a few specific learning goals for final weeks, remind them to complete their self-assessments plan with students to do something on last clinical day to thank the nursing staff and show their appreciation (thank you card and food) ? please wait for the end of the narration to proceed please click each bubble to learn more

continue to assess and evaluate student learning review anecdotal notes and clinical practice expectations to ensure continued growth and development prepare formative assessments, review student self assessments, complete online final evaluations, share final evaluation with students (module #3) maintain effective relationships with staff summary: winding down the clinical rotation

: clinical day organizer 2 part 4 : clinical day organizer 2 part 3 : clinical day organizer 2 part 2 : clinical day organizer 2 part 1 : clinical day organizer 1 : clinical day checklist part 3 : clinical day checklist part 2 : clinical day checklist part 1 providing organizational tools clinical day checklist clinical day checklist clinical day checklist clinical day organizer clinical day organizer clinical day organizer click each button to view the resources: click each button to view the resources: helps students learn how to organize and prioritize their nursing care throughout the clinical day. clinical preparation guides help students consider the “bigger picture” as they begin researching their patient’s: diagnosis medications lab results diagnostic tests social and/or developmental context. patient assignment “cheat sheets”, offer students a quick way to document handover information and develop a timeline of nursing care for their patient. effective clinical teaching

how are things going? is there anything i can help you with? there's nothing to do! we’re kinda bored. scenario: a bump in the road during week 6 of the 7-week clinical rotation, aubrey's students have been progressing well and are comfortably caring for one complex or two less complex patients. while touching base with each student and engaging in clinical coaching, aubrey notices two students at the nursing station. they appear unengaged with providing nursing care for their patients and are chatting with each other about their plans for the weekend. …my sister and i will be going to yorkdale on saturday, and then…

scenario: think & reflect what would your response be if you were aubrey? can you think of any learning activities that might keep these students engaged at this time? type your first response here type your response here

preparation preparation implementation winding down design scavenger hunt design scavenger hunt design scavenger hunt intentional rounding intentional rounding intentional rounding post-clinical conference post-clinical conference post-clinical conference discuss midterm clinical progress with students discuss midterm clinical progress with students discuss midterm clinical progress with students prepare patient assignment prepare patient assignment prepare patient assignment send welcome email to students send welcome email to students send welcome email to students assess student learning assess student learning assess student learning review patient pathophysiology with student review patient pathophysiology with student review patient pathophysiology with student write final clinical evaluations write final clinical evaluations write final clinical evaluations review clinical practice expectations review clinical practice expectations review clinical practice expectations deliver clinical orientation deliver clinical orientation deliver clinical orientation provide clinical supervision provide clinical supervision provide clinical supervision foster and maintain effective relationships with staff foster and maintain effective relationships with staff foster and maintain effective relationships with staff review anecdotal clinical notes one last time review anecdotal clinical notes one last time review anecdotal clinical notes one last time provide common patient diagnoses and medications provide common patient diagnoses and medications provide common patient diagnoses and medications knowledge check sort the clinical teaching tools / activities on the right with their associated phase of the clinical rotation on the left. some will belong to more than one phase, in which case you can drop them in either phase.
implementation phase
my checklist: clinical teaching strategies and approaches i will implement to ensure my effectiveness during the clinical rotation type your first text here clinical orientation: reflect & consider

back back back back back back 3 of 3 seek out opportunities communicate with multi-d team encourage reflection and reflective practice frequent check-ins with emotional state build confidence by encouraging connect learning with nclex time management, learning opportunities ensure that students take breaks (schedule them), encourage self care help students know their limits, encourage shared learning please read each sticky note before moving on! more more more more more more back back back back back back keep chart of who has done what be aware of and explore boundaries 2 of 3 explain responsibilities of students to unit staff talk to charge nurse for good patient assignments, assess acuity of pts, review student need, assess student comfort, assign students pts they can handle weekly post conferences weekly post conferences presentations / in-services from interprofessionals prepare and provide final evaluations increase workload (1-2 or 3 pts as appropriate) access online learning modules please read each sticky note before moving on! examples of previous cis’ ideas facilitate orientation - unit tour, shadow nurses, demo skills, review expectations, cpes, worksheet examples, scavenger hunt, ppt, show unit supplies, practice manual bp keep chart of who has done what spend time with interprofessional team review head to toe assessment beforehand daily activity sheet, student time plan more more more more more more 1 of 3 provide lots of real time feedback encourage students to be self-directed ask students what skills/experiences they would like to do / have teach and review bpgs; role model best practices click each sticky note to reveal their ideas! please read each sticky note before moving on!

implementing effective clinical teaching during the clinical rotation: summary plan for a successful first day of clinical select appropriate patient assignments and other learning activities provide clinical supervision (direct & indirect) and ensure safe patient care (module #1) facilitate clinical learning through skillful questioning and clinical debriefing (module #4) provide ongoing feedback to students (module #3) facilitate weekly clinical conferences maintain excellent clinical / anecdotal notes for each student

effective clinical teaching preparing patient assignments preparing patient assignments preparing patient assignments providing organizational tools providing organizational tools providing organizational tools keeping detailed clinical notes keeping detailed clinical notes keeping detailed clinical notes facilitating clinical conferences facilitating clinical conferences facilitating clinical conferences intentional role modeling intentional role modeling intentional role modeling click each resource type to learn more: + please wait for the explanation to finish

example of student notes collected during the clinical rotation. during the day or during post-conference, the ci can ask, “what new/cool things have you done this week?” and include it under “new skills learned.” the ci can also get feedback from the nurses to suggest what students can improve on the next week. the ci can share this chart at midterm and print the entire document to share during their final evaluation. our ci who developed and uses this document/approach, claims the “students love this” and “it helps with writing final evaluations (adding specific examples), provides the student with a memory of their clinical placement, and can help with their interview process as they recall their clinical experience on the unit.” keeping detailed clinical notes sample weekly clinical notes sample weekly clinical notes sample weekly clinical notes click the button to view the resource: essential to properly assess and evaluate student progress and plan clinical teaching activities documents may include anecdotal notes clinical skills checklists student worksheets summaries of formative mid-term assessments or discussions summative final clinical evaluations. one resource provided here is an example of making clinical notes for a student. effective clinical teaching

intentional role modeling think about one of your professional role models... now think about how they have influenced your nursing identity - who you are as a nurse and how you practice the craft of nursing. formation: during their formal education, nursing students are continually ‘forming’ their nursing identity, skilled know-how, knowledge use, and character, including their moral formation. benner 2008 as someone who sets a positive example, displays professional attitudes and values, and is worthy of imitation, the clinical instructor guides and facilitates the development or ‘formation’ of nursing students’ professional identity. is an extremely valuable and effective effective clinical teaching necessitates that the clinical instructor be fully aware of being a role model requires that the clinical instructor has time to teach emphasizes the importance of critical reflection provides an opportunity for the clinical instructor to make the implicit aspect of nursing, explicit (cruess et al., 2008). clinical teaching strategy. role models inspire and teach by example.

intentional role modeling: what to do when? 1 2 effective clinical teaching scenario 1 scenario 2 please begin with scenario 1 please click the scenario 1 image please click the scenario 2 image please wait for the explanation to finish

incorrect please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue incorrect close this text box to reveal the correct order of andy’s intentional role modeling to effectively support his student experiencing a challenging clinical situation while demonstrating and teaching the art of nursing. andy plans to engage the student in some critical reflection after leaving the patient's room... it will be important to debrief this clinical experience and discuss the student's perspective regarding what went well, not so well, and what they might do differently next time. x correct order: correct you have created a step by step clinical example of how andy used intentional role modeling to effectively support his student experiencing a challenging clinical situation while demonstrating and teaching the art of nursing. andy plans to engage the student in some critical reflection after leaving the patient's room... it will be important to debrief this clinical experience and discuss the student's perspective regarding what went well, not so well, and what they might do differently next time. continue continue continue continue continue continue 1 2 3 4 5 6 praise child for doing a great job and give them a sticker signifying the end of the assessment. engage child through play and include student in game you are playing. begin to assess child without touching them (rr, work of breathing), talking to student about what you are both observing. respond to parents' questions saying, "you have some very important questions. we need to complete our assessment of your child and then we'll have time to answer your questions". enter child's room, introduce self, and let student know you are there to complete child's morning assessment with them. after encouraging child to play with your stethoscope and listen to student's heart, you tell them that now student is going to listen to their heart. when child becomes upset while you and student auscultate their anterior lung sounds, you encourage parent to hold child on their lap. after child settles, you and student continue assessing their posterior lung sounds and complete the assessment. temporary step holder intentional role modeling: scenario 1, andy’s approach effective clinical teaching drag and drop the steps into the correct order, then click the submit check mark at bottom right. use the temporary step holder space to hold a step as you order them. you have 3 attempts. x

this scenario highlights the importance of being prepared to capitalize on downtime at any point in the clinical rotation. the ci has a responsibility to identify meaningful learning strategies to engage students during downtime. it is important for the ci to prepare individual and group learning activities to keep students engaged during downtime. in this scenario, aubrey used a case study that she had prepared to engage the students and fill a gap in their clinical practice experience. other activities to consider: simulation role play games virtual simulation unfolding clinical case scenario medication quiz practice discharge preparation and teaching concept maps problem-based learning mini-nursing care plan in-service or learning poster for the unit intentional rounding embrace downtime as an opportunity to maximize learning! aubrey in action: downtime i see. have you finished your charting for the day? no, that’s why we are sitting here… and why we’re bored. yes. we both just finished charting. thank you, aubrey! we’ll get to work on this now. no, we asked them a few minutes ago and they said they didn’t need any help. ok, well, i am happy to hear that you offered to help, and that your charting is finished. do your patients need anything between now and our post conference in 45 minutes? i have heard a few of the nurses talk about their last patient with fibromyalgia and was wondering what it was. this looks like an interesting activity. i see. hmmm… i have an idea. why don’t you work through this case study i designed earlier this week. here are some copies. the case is about a patient who is admitted to the unit with a diagnosis of fibromyalgia. this is a diagnosis we often see on this unit, but haven’t yet during this rotation. the first page outlines the patient’s background, history, clinical presentation, and admissions assessment. then there are five questions for you to answer, which have been structured to help guide you through researching the diagnosis, pathophysiology, nursing care, medications, and safety considerations. you can work on this together and then share what you’ve learned during our post conference. how does this sound? oh, good! do any of the nurses need help with anything?
effective clinical teaching intentional role modeling: scenario 1 andy
effective clinical teaching intentional role modeling: scenario 2

this approach does not represent intentional role modeling; rather, it illustrates how a ci might attempt to provide a supportive learning environment by sharing their approach and expectations for the student's participation during rounds with the team. this approach might be used with senior students towards the end of their clinical rotation who have been slow to develop their interprofessional communication and collaboration skills... and who need to demonstrate competency to their ci. it may not be appropriate for all students. x this type of intentional role modeling is important as it provides students with the encouragment or prompting they sometimes need as they develop more confidence and competence with interprofessional team communication. the ci recognizes the student's ability to contribute information independently while needing some support with team collaborating on a plan of care for the patient. this approach is most appropriate for this scenario as the student is a senior and it is midway through the clinical rotation. this approach might also be appropriate for more junior students towards the end of the clinical rotation. x this type of intentional role modeling is important as it provides students with a safe and supportive opportunity to participate and contribute relevant patient assessment findings as prompted by their ci. by actively observing the ci collaborate with the team to determine next steps, the student should develop more experience and confidence with how they might participate in rounds the next time. this approach is most appropriate for junior students and/or students at the beginning of a new clinical rotation. x this type of intentional role modeling is important as it provides students with an example of how the nurse can communicate specific and relevant patient assessment details during team rounds. this approach is most appropriate for students in their first clinical rotation and/or students at the beginning of a new clinical rotation. x how might you use intentional role modeling to support this student? intentional role modeling: scenario 2 4 remain outside the rounding team, introduce self as student's ci, explain learning goal for student to practice more independent participation during rounds, and encourage student to go ahead and provide their assessment findings at this time. 2 join the student in rounds, introduce self as student's ci, encourage the student to provide a short summary of the patient's morning assessment and any changes within the last 12 hours, and then together actively participate in the team discussion to help determine a plan of care for the patient. 3 join the student in rounds, introduce self as student's ci, begin to provide the patient's assessment findings while asking the student to share specific vital signs and significant changes within the last 12 hours, and then you collaborate with the team to determine next steps. 1 join the student in rounds, introduce self as student's ci, provide the patient's assessment findings on the students's behalf, ask the student if there is anything else they want to add, and then continue to engage in the team discussion. select this option select this option select this option select this option select this option select this option select this option select this option select this option select this option select this option select this option effective clinical teaching

the importance of establishing and maintaining effective relationships with students and staff to create a supportive learning environment. the characteristics of an effective clinical teacher. four column layout module summary by completing this module you have learned about: the many clinical teaching strategies that will support you through the three phases of the clinical rotation – planning, implementing and winding down. the various clinical teaching resources available for you to use during your clinical rotation.
